title-group.article-title: Discovery of novel disulfide-containing PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor with in vivo influenza therapeutic efficacy

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/01y2kdt21grid.444883.70000 0001 2109 9431Faculty of Pharmacy, Osaka Medical and Pharmaceutical University, Takatsuki, Osaka Japan

abstract.p: Monoclonal antibody-based immune checkpoint inhibitors, which have brought breakthrough effects in cancer treatments, are expected to assist in the treatment of viral diseases. However, antibody therapies may cause immune-related side effects, such as inflammation and pneumonia, due to cytokine storms. Small-molecule PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors are an alternative to monoclonal antibody-based therapeutics. We have identified a novel small-molecule PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor having a functional group (disulfide group), namely compound 2 (molecular weight: 456.6), from our library of sulfur-containing protein–protein interaction inhibitor compounds. Compound 2 selectively bound to PD-L1 over PD-1, with the dissociation rate constant (KD) of 77.60 ± 4.44 nM (obtained by affinity analysis) and showed promising T cell activation recovery. A molecular docking simulation study between 2 and PD-L1 suggested that 2 binds to PD-L1 in a binding mode different from those of other small-molecule PD-L1/PD-1 inhibitors. Notably, oral administration of 2 to mice pre-infected with influenza A virus (A/NWS/33, H1N1 subtype) caused a significant increase in the neutralizing antibody titers, as well as recovery from influenza-induced pneumonia. Overall, 2 provides insight for the development of therapeutic drugs against early viral infections, with both virus titer-reducing and antibody titer-boosting effects. Moreover, 2 is widely used as a rubber peptizing agent in the production process of tires and other rubber products. Our findings may provide useful information for investigating its influence on living organisms.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41598-025-17982-3.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Antagonistic substances against immune checkpoint proteins, such as programmed cell death 1 (PD-1), programmed cell death-ligand 1 (PD-L1), and cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 (CTLA4), were initially developed as anticancer treatments because cancers exploit these proteins to evade detection by the immune system. To date, eight monoclonal antibodies (anti-PD-1 antibodies: nivolumab, pembrolizumab, and cemiplimab; anti-PD-L1 antibodies: atezolizumab, avelumab, and durvalumab; anti-CTLA4 antibodies: ipilimumab and tremelimumab) have been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration1–12. Additionally, as next-generation immune checkpoint inhibitors, the antibodies against lymphocyte activation gene 3 (LAG-3), T cell immunoglobulin and mucin-domain-containing-3 (TIM-3), and T cell immunoreceptor with Ig and ITIM domains (TIGIT) are under pre-clinical or clinical trials13,14. These antibodies have been exclusively applied to cancer treatments, and further applications are anticipated against viral infectious diseases such as influenza15, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy16, human immunodeficiency virus disease17, and hepatitis B and hepatitis C18. However, the antibody therapies can sometimes cause immune-related adverse effects, including inflammation or pneumonia, due to cytokine storm19,20. Furthermore, several problems persist: high production costs, a lack of oral administration, a short half-life, and poor penetration in organs and tumors. Therefore, the development of low-molecular-weight compounds that antagonize the immune checkpoint proteins is warranted. Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMS) has designed numerous nonpeptidic small molecular PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors21–23. They successfully synthesized two types of inhibitors: (2-methyl-3-biphenylyl)methanol derivatives and [3-(2,3-dihydro-1,4-benzodioxin-6-yl)-2-methylphenyl]methanol derivatives. X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that these derivatives bound to the center of the PD-L1 homodimer, filling a deep hydrophobic channel-like pocket between two PD-L1 molecules. Additionally, the two optimized BMS compounds, BMS-1001 and BMS-1166, bound to human PD-L1, induced PD-L1 protein dimerization, and blocked its interaction with human PD-121–23. Various other small-molecule immune checkpoint inhibitors have been reported24–28. Recently, CA-17029,30, a dual inhibitor of PD-L1 and VISTA, has reached Phase 2b/3 clinical trials. This compound blocks PD-L1 signaling without preventing the assembly of the PD-1/PD-L1 complex and shows anti-tumor efficacy. Moreover, clinical trials are currently ongoing to the anticancer potency of the PD-L1-specific inhibitors GS 4224, INCB086550, and IMMH-01031.

We previously hypothesized that some thiol- or disulfide-containing compounds can disrupt protein–protein interactions (PPIs) by binding to the cysteine-cysteine disulfide or cysteine-thiol of proteins, respectively, via thiol-disulfide exchange reactions, potentially allowing for the separation of bound proteins. Based on this hypothesis, we designed a series of sulfur-containing compounds to screen for Murine double minute 4 (Mdmx) inhibitors, and ultimately identified K-178 (8), which selectively inhibited the binding of p53 with Mdmx over the binding of p53 with other partners, including Murine double minute 2 (Mdm2)[ 32 ].

In this study, we searched for new PD-1/PD-L1 binding inhibitors from our library of sulfur-based and related compounds, aiming to perform oral administration experiments using mice pre-infected with influenza virus (IFV). The screening for PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors by ELISA led to the identification of 2-benzamido diphenyl disulfide (2), which inhibited the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction with an IC50 of 5.7–6.2 nM (Sect. 1 in Supplementary Information), comparable to the reported IC50 (6–100 nM) of the positive control, BMS-1 33–38. The surface plasmon resonance (SPR) analysis confirmed that compound 2 selectively bound to PD-L1 over PD-1 with an equilibrium dissociation rate constant (KD) of 77.60 ± 4.44 nM. Furthermore, the T cell activation recovery assay suggested that 2 has a T cell-activating effect similar to that of CA-170. Notably, 2 showed promising therapeutic effect after oral administration to mice that were intranasally pre-infected with IFV (A/NWS/33, H1N1 subtype) and increased the neutralizing antibody titers. These results suggest that 2 represents a new drug candidate for viral infections with both virus titer-reducing and antibody titer-enhancing effects.

sec.title: Identification of new type of PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor 2 by ELISA analysis
sec.p:
For the first screening, we assessed the inhibition effect of the dimeric disulfide compounds (1, 2, 3, 4a–e, and 5) and the monomeric sulfur-containing compounds (6, 7, 8, 9, and 10), together with BMS-1 (positive control) (Fig. 1A), on the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction by ELISA. We incubated the test compounds (all at 10 μM) with the biotinylated PD-1 Fc Chimera (0.25 μM) on a Ni-coated plate with immobilized His-tagged PD-L1 (0.25 μM). Then, we successively treated the plates with horseradish-peroxidase (HRP)-bound streptavidin and the coloring agent tetramethylbenzidine (TMB), as indicated in the experimental Sect. “Methods”. We calculated the proportion of PD-1-bound PD-L1 by dividing the absorbance at 450 nm of the wells containing test compounds by the absorbance of wells containing no test compound (control). As shown in Figs. 1B, compound 2 and BMS-1 inhibited 76% and 58% of the PD-1/PD-L1 binding, respectively. Meanwhile, 4a, 3, and 8 inhibited 34%, 34%, and 39% of the PD1/PD-L1 binding, respectively, and the pyridinyl ring-possessing compounds 4b–d and the meta-isomer of 2 (5) barely inhibited the interaction. Although the monomeric sulfide derivative of 2 (6) reduced binding by 21%, this value fluctuated with each measurement (data not shown). We speculate that 6 was partially converted into the dimer 2 by air oxidation during incubation, which may have contributed to the protein–protein binding inhibition. Next, to investigate the structure–activity relationship, we compared the inhibition efficacies of 2 and 6 with the meta- and para-isomers of 2 (5 and 11), 6 (12 and 13), and 8 (14 and 15), as well as with CH2-O bioisostere (16) and oxygen-substituted compounds 17 and 18 (Fig. 1A).Fig. 1
Screening of sulfur-containing compounds for the inhibition of PD-1/PD-L1 interaction by ELISA. (A) Test compounds. (B) First screening results. (C) Second screening results. Each value is the mean ± standard error of the mean from triplicate measurements. *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01 versus the control (0.1% DMSO). The experiments were repeated more than three times to ensure reliability.Fig. 2
Characterization of the PD-1/PDL1 interaction inhibitors by SPR. (A) Representative sensorgram of PD-1 on immobilized PD-L1. (B) Representative sensorgrams of PD-1 on immobilized PD-L1 in the presence or absence of tested compounds. As a control, 1% DMSO was used. (C) Representative sensorgrams of 2 on immobilized PD-L1 or PD-1. (D) The fitting curve of the response measured at equilibrium plotted against the compound 2 concentration. All experiments were repeated more than three times to ensure reliability.

As shown in Fig. 1C, except for BMS-1 and compound 2, none of the test compounds exhibited noticeable inhibitory activity. Thus, compound 2 has a PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitory activity similar to that of BMS-1.

sec.title: Determination of the binding preference of compound 2 to PD-L1 over PD-1 by surface plasmon resonance (SPR)
sec.p: Subsequently, we performed SPR to confirm the above results39–41. First, we conducted the PD-L1/PD-1 binding assay using His-tagged PD-L1 as a ligand and PD-1 Fc Chimera as an analyte. We immobilized His-tagged PD-L1 (1.0 μM) on a Biacore Sensor Chip CM5. Then, we injected the PD-1 Fc Chimera (0.001, 0.125, 0.25, 0.5, and 1.0 μM) over the immobilized PD-L1. As shown in Fig. 2A, the resonance unit (RU) decreased with decreasing concentrations of PD-1. Second, we pre-mixed the test compounds (0.1 or 0.01 μM) with the PD-1 Fc Chimera (0.1 μM) and injected them over the immobilized His-tagged PD-L1 (Fig. 2B). BMS-1 and 2 (both 0.01 μM) decreased the experimental maximum binding responses (Rmax) to 56% and 71% of the control value (Rmax = 1090 RU), respectively. Increasing the concentration of BMS-1 and 2 from 0.01 to 0.1 μM decreased the Rmax values to 40% and 50% of the control, respectively. These results suggest that 2 inhibited the PD-L1/PD-1 binding at similar levels to BMS-1. Third, we investigated whether compound 2 bound to either PD-L1 or PD-1. We injected His-tagged PD-L1 (1.0 μM) or PD-1 Fc Chimera (1.0 μM) on a Biacore Sensor Chip CM5 to immobilize them. Then, we injected 2 (0.01, 0.1, 0.5, or 1.0 μM) through a ligand cell (immobilized His-tagged PD-L1 or PD-1 Fc Chimera) or a reference cell. As shown in Fig. 2C, compound 2 bound to PD-L1 but not PD-1. The KD of 2 binding to PD-L1 was calculated to be 77.60 ± 4.44 nM by affinity analysis from the curve fitted to the RU values at equilibrium versus the concentrations of 2 (Fig. 2D).

sec.title: T-cell activation recovery assay
sec.p:
To evaluate the capability of 2 to prevent T cell inactivation through PD-L1, we planned to co-culture MDA-MB-231 cells with Jurkat (E6-1) cells pre-activated with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 antibodies in the presence of 2 or related compounds, namely 5 and 11, and assessed γ-interferon (IFN-γ) and interleukin 2 (IL-2) production by ELISA. Prior to conducting tests, we confirmed the expression of PD-L1 on MDA-MB-231 cells and PD-1 on Jurkat (E6-1) cells activated with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 antibodies, respectively, by Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorting (FACS) (see Sect. 2 in Supplementary Information). In the following tests, we used CA-170, BMS-1, and BMS-1166 as reference compounds. First, we evaluated the cell viability of Jurkat (E6-1) and MDA-MB-231 cells treated with these compounds (1, 10 and 100 µ M) by WST-8 assay (Dojindo, Kumamoto, Japan) (Fig. 3A). The viability of Jurkat (E6-1) cells treated with 2, CA-170 and BMS-1166 remained above 85% compared with the control at 1 and 10 μM, while BMS-1, 5 and 11 reduced it to 58.6%, 74.9% and 67.5%, respectively, at 10 μM. The viability of MDA-MB-231 cells treated with 1 and 10 µM of the test compounds remained above 80% except for BMS-1 (78.1% at 10 µM). As shown in Fig. 3B, CA-170 and 2 significantly increased the IFN-γ and IL-2 levels at a non-/low-toxic concentration (10 μM) relative to the control (containing pre-activated Jurkat (E6-1) cells and MDA-MB-231). Compound 2 increased the IFN-γ level by 54.9% at 10 µM, and the IL-2 level by 130% at 10 µM. In Fig. 3C, we examined the effect of compound 2 on cytokine secretion in MDA-MB-231 cells or in Jurkat (E6-1), together with BMS-1 as a reference compound. The results showed that 2 had little effect on the cytokine secretion from MDA-MB-231 cells (see blue dotted lines), whereas it somewhat inhibited the cytokine secretion from activated Jurkat (E6-1) cells (black dotted lines). However, the triple combination of compound 2, MDA-MB-231 and activated Jurkat (E6-1) cells promoted cytokine production (Fig. 3B), leading us to conclude that 2 has promising T cell activation recovery activity.Fig. 3
Effect of 2 and related compounds on IFN-γ and IL-2 secretion from Jurkat T cells. (A) Jurkat (E6-1) and MDA-MB-231 cell viability. *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01 versus the control (0.1% DMSO/medium). (B), (C) IFN-γ and IL-2 secretion from Jurkat (E6-1) cells. The cytokine secretions in Jurkat (+ anti-CD3/CD28) + MDA-MB-231 were used as controls in B. The cytokine secretions in MDA-MB-231 only and in Jurkat (+ anti-CD3/CD28) only were used as controls, respectively, in (C). Each value is the mean ± standard error of the mean from triplicate measurements. *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01 versus control. All experiments were repeated more than three times and yielded similar results.

sec.title: Docking simulation of BMS-202 and compound 2 into the PD-L1 dimer
sec.p:
As shown in Fig. 4A, BMS-1 and BMS-202 have virtually the same pharmacophore. Based on the hypothesis that the hydrophobic part of these compounds and that of compound 2 overlap, we docked 2 with the PD-L1 dimer based on the X-ray data of the PD-L1 tetramer co-crystallized with BMS-202 (PDB: 5J89)21. We conducted the computer simulation using Molecular Operating Environment (MOE) 2028.09. Figure 4B displays the area around the docking site of BMS-202 to the PD-L1 dimer. The letters c and d label amino acids belonging to the PD-L1 dimers PD-L1C and PD-L1D21. BMS-202 is stabilized by π-alkyl interactions between aromatic ring A and MetC115, and aromatic ring B and AlaC121. Furthermore, the pyridine ring (C ring) in the linker part of BMS-202 forms a tight hydrophobic interaction with AspC122, whereas the +NH2 and NH of the hydrocarbon chain of BMS-202 form electrostatic interactions with the carbonyl and hydroxyl of the carboxylic acid in AspC122, respectively, enhancing the fit of the linker part of BMS-202 in the cleft at the dimeric interface. Meanwhile, the docking of compound 2 on the PD-L1 dimer (Fig. 4C) revealed no interaction between the aromatic ring (A ring) of the benzoylamido group and MetC115 or AlaC121. Instead, the sulfur atom of the disulfide bond of 2 forms a non-covalent sulfur-disulfide interaction with MetD11542. In addition, the carbonyl group of 2 forms a hydrogen bond with the NH of TyrC123, and the aromatic ring D of 2 binds to the pocket through a π-alkyl interaction with AsnD 63. Figure 4D shows a simulated docking diagram.Fig. 4
Docking diagram of BMS-202 and compound 2 with the PD-L1 dimer. (A) Pharmacophores of BMS-1, BMS-202, and 2. (B) Docking of BMS-202 with the PD-L1 dimer. (C) Docking of 2 with the PD-L1 dimer. (D) Superimposed models of BMS-202 (magenta) and 2 (cyan) in the PD-L1 dimer.

where BMS-202 (magenta) and 2 (cyan) overlap. The A, B, and C rings of both compounds are well superimposed. However, the disulfide bond linkage in 2 binds to the cleft with a slightly different conformation from the corresponding linker in BMS-202 because MetD115 draws the sulfur atom of the disulfide bond in 2 upward. Considering that compound 16, with –CH2–O– instead of the disulfide linkage, did not inhibit PD-1/PD-L1 binding, the non-covalent interaction between the sulfur of 2 and MetD115 may play an important role in the inhibition of the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction.

sec.title: Oral administration of compound 2, 7, and oseltamivir to mice with IFV (A/NWS/33, H1N1 subtype)
sec.p:
We orally administered 2, its monomeric prodrug 7 (each 1 mg/mouse/day), and oseltamivir (0.2 mg/mouse/day) (suspended in distilled water) to BALB/c mice (n = 10 per group) after intranasal inoculation of IFV (day 0). We evaluated their therapeutic efficacies on IFV-infected mice by monitoring the body weight, survival rate, virus yields in lungs, and neutralizing antibody titers in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluids (BALFs) and serum. Mice infected with IFV did not show symptoms, such as sneezing or nasal discharge. We determined the severity of influenza symptoms based on the weight loss associated with a decrease in appetite due to the onset of pneumonia. The groups treated with 2 and 7 gradually lost body weight until one week after infection, but not as much as the control group. Additionally, 2- and 7-treated mice rapidly recovered weight and returned to their original weight two weeks after infection (Fig. 5A). Therefore, these compounds alleviated the symptoms of viral infection. All mice in all groups survived. On day 3, compounds 2 and 7 had reduced the virus yields in the lungs to 45% (p < 0.01) and 56% (p < 0.01) relative to the control, respectively, and oseltamivir had reduced it to 11% (p < 0.001) (Fig. 5B). We assessed the effects of the compounds on neutralizing antibody responses to IFV infection in serum and BALF samples on days 3 and 14. On day 3, the antibody titers in the sera of the three administration groups were almost equivalent to that of the control, and there was no significant difference between them (Fig. 5C). Antibody titers in the lungs could not be measured due to residual virus. On day 14, 2 increased the antibody titers 2.4-fold in BALFs (Fig. 5D) and 1.7-fold in sera (Fig. 5E) compared with the control group (each p < 0.05). Meanwhile, 7 moderately increased the antibody titers. In contrast, oseltamivir significantly suppressed antibody production compared with the control.Fig. 5
Effects of 2 and 7 on the weight, influenza A virus titers, and neutralizing antibody titers in mice. (A) Body weight change for 14 days. (B) Virus titers (× 105 plaque-forming units/100 mg) in lung samples of mice on day 3. **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001 versus control mice (distilled water). (C) Neutralizing antibody titers in sera on day 3. (D) Neutralizing antibody titers in BALFs on day 14. *p < 0.05 versus control mice. (E) Neutralizing antibody titers in sera on day 14. *p < 0.05 versus control mice.

sec.title: In vitro anti-influenza virus activity of compound 2
sec.p: In order to investigate the possibility that the influenza therapeutic effect of compound 2 is due to its direct antiviral activity, we evaluated the in vitro antiviral activity of 2 against IFV. The CC50 of 2 was 20 ± 2.1 µg/mL against Madin–Darby canine kidney epithelial (MDCK) cells. The EC50 of 2 was 110 ± 9.2 µg/mL. The resulting selectivity index (CC50/EC50) was 0.18 ± 0.035.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The ELISA and SPR assays demonstrated that 2 inhibited the PD-1/PD-L1 binding and selectively bound to PD-L1 over PD-1. Furthermore, the T-cell activation recovery results suggested that 2 activated T cell function by inhibiting the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction. We initially inferred that the disulfide group of 2 bounded with a thiol of cysteine in the PD-L1 binding pocket through a thiol-disulfide exchange reaction. However, the docking simulation suggested that one sulfur atom of the disulfide group of 2 interacted non-covalently with the sulfur atom of MetD115, assisting the binding between 2 and the PD-L1 dimer. We speculate that this interaction, as well as the electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions by the carbonyl and aromatic D ring of 2, respectively, could compensate for the lack of electrostatic binding sites, which are present in BMS-1 and BMS-202. This binding mode involving a disulfide group has not been found in previous small-molecule PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors.

The oral administration of 2 to mice after the intranasal infection of IFV (A/NWS/33, H1N1 subtype) not only alleviated symptoms and reduced viral production in the lung, but also increased neutralizing antibody titers. It is well known that there are concerns in the development of vaccines against viral diseases, such as COVID-19 and influenza, and that antibody levels are not maintained over the long term43,44. There are several reports regarding the application of immune checkpoint inhibitors to treat viral diseases15–18. However, they have not been used in practice due to the risk of side effects such as an excessive immune activation (immune-related pneumonia)19,20. Compound 2 rescued mice from influenza-induced pneumonia and induced a high increase in neutralizing antibody titers. In general, when a compound has a selectivity index greater than 10, it can be regarded as possessing in vitro antiviral activity. Compound 2 showed the selectivity index of 0.18 ± 0.035, strongly suggesting that its antiviral effect is not due to a direct inhibition of viral replication in the influenza virus-infected mice. Furthermore, since compound 2 blocked not only human PD-1/PD-L1 interaction, but also mouse PD-1/PD-L1 interaction in ELISA (see Sect. 3 in Supplementary Information), it is most likely that 2 rescued mice from influenza-induced pneumonia through a mechanism involving inhibition of PD-1/PD-L1 interaction. We anticipate that 2 or a similar compound may be used as a new type of therapeutic drug for virus-infected patients that can extend the vaccine effectiveness. Notably, 2 also selectively inhibited HDAC6 (see Sect. 4 in Supplementary Information). Since inhibiting HDAC6 downregulates PD-L1 expression45, 2 may act as a dual targeting inhibitor. These findings strongly support the application of 2 or related compounds in therapeutics for viral diseases, including early stage infectious diseases17,46–48.

Small molecule immune checkpoint inhibitors are generally less effective than antibody drugs, and there are concerns about side effects due to off-target effects, making their development difficult. However, some small molecule drugs having multiple mechanisms of action on the market are referred to as “dirty drugs,” and are actually more effective than drugs with a single mechanism. Since small molecule immune checkpoint inhibitors are expected to possess many advantages compared to the antibody drugs as described at the beginning, they might have a potential to be used as medicines particularly for early symptoms of diseases. For example, they might be developed as medicines for early symptoms of coronavirus infection and influenza virus infection as described above, because their efficacies are somewhat milder than those of the antibody drugs.

Compound 2 is commercially available as 2’,2’’’-dithiobisbenzanilide (DTBBA) and is used as a rubber peptizing agent in the manufacturing process of tires and other rubber products. Additionally, the tire and rubber wear particles are distributed in the environment49–53. However, only a few studies have considered the effect of DTBBA on living organisms49–51. We believe that our paper will provide valuable information for investigating the effects on organisms.

sec.title: Ethics statement
sec.p: Committees from the Faculty of Pharmacy, Osaka Medical and Pharmaceutical University, and Faculty of Chemistry, Materials and Bioengineering, Kansai University approved the experimental protocols. All animal experiments were performed in accordance with the animal experimentation guidelines of Chubu University and were approved by the Animal Care Committee of Chubu University (permission number: 3010057). All infections and sample collections were conducted under anesthesia with sodium pentobarbital (50 mg/kg), and human endpoints were used during the study, that is, animals with > 20% weight loss within 2 days were sacrificed using sodium pentobarbital treatment (150 mg/kg). The results were reported in accordance with ARRIVE guidelines. No side effects such as diarrhea were observed due to drug administration throughout the experiments.

sec.title: General procedures
sec.p: BMS-1 and BMS-1166 were purchased from Cayman Chemical (MI, USA), and CA-170 was purchased from MedChem Express (NJ, USA). We described the synthetic methods of compounds 1–3, 6–8, and 17 in our previous paper32. The synthesis of all other compounds and purity of test compounds are provided as Sects. 5 and 6 in Supplementary Information, respectively. The PD-1/PD-L1 inhibition assay and SPR analysis were performed using PD-1 Fc Chimera and His-tagged PD-L1, which we purchased from Genscript (NJ, USA) and Sino Biological (Beijing, China), respectively. We purchased Biacore T200 from Cytiva (MA, USA).

sec.title: Cells and virus
sec.p: MDCK cells and IFV (A/NWS/33, H1N1 subtype) were obtained from Denka Seiken Co., Ltd. (Tokyo, Japan). The cells were grown in minimum essential medium (MEM) supplemented with 5% fetal bovine serum, 100 units/mL penicillin G and 100 mg/mL streptomycin. Jurkat cells (E6-1) and MDA-MB-231cells were purchased from American Type Culture Collection (ATCC).

sec.title: Biotinylation of PD-1
sec.p: We biotinylated the PD-1 Fc Chimera using a CromaLink® Biotin labeling kit (TriLink, CA, USA) and desalted it by ultrafiltration using a 10 kDa-cutoff Vivaspin column (Cytiva, MA, USA). We determined the degree of biotinylation by employing a 4’-hydroxyazobenzene-2-carboxylic acid (HABA) assay54. Briefly, we added a solution of biotinylated PD-1 in deionized water (20 μL) to an aliquot (180 μL) of a mixture of avidin (5 mg) and HABA (726 μg) in PBS (9.7 mL) and deionized water (300 μL, containing 1N NaOH (3 μL)) (Pierce Chemical Co., Rockford, IL, USA). We then measured the absorbance at 500 nm using a microplate reader. The biotinylation percentage, calculated by dividing the biotynilated protein concentration by the total protein concentration, was approximately 0.27/protein.

sec.title: PD-1/PD-L1 inhibition assay with ELISA
sec.p: We treated Ni-coated 96-well plates (Thermo Scientific Pierce, MA, USA) with 0.25 μM/100 μL/well of His-tagged PD-L1 and washed them using Tris-buffered saline with Tween 20 (TBS-T) (pH 7.2). We plotted standard curves using the wells with 0–1.0 μM/mL biotinylated PD-1 Fc Chimera in each plate. We diluted the test compounds or BMS-1 (all at 10 mM in DMSO) in 20% Blocking One (Nacalai Tesque, Kyoto, Japan) to reach 100 μM. Next, we placed the mixture (100 μL) of the compound (10 μL, final concentration: 10 μM) and PD-1 (90 μL, final concentration: 0.25 μM) into the 96-well plate with His-tagged PD-L1. After incubation for 1 h, we washed the plate with TBST (pH 7.2) and detected bound PD-1 by adding streptavidin-HRP (R&D Systems, MN, USA) and then colorizing with a TMB solution (Nacalai Tesque, Kyoto, Japan) in a conventional manner. We calculated percentage binding ratios by diving the absorbance at 450 nm obtained from the co-incubation of PD-1/PD-L1 and test compound by the absorbance obtained from the incubation of these proteins alone.

sec.title: SPR analysis
sec.p: We performed the binding assay of PD-L1 and PD-1 and evaluated the inhibition of the PD-L1 and PD-1 interaction using a Biacore T200 system with a Sensor Chip CM5 (Cytiva, MA, USA). We injected His-tagged PD-L1 (final concentration: 1.0 μM) in sodium acetate buffer (pH 4.0) through a ligand cell to allow immobilization on the Sensor Chip CM5 by condensation between -COOH and NH2- using N-hydroxysuccinimide and water-soluble carbodiimide hydrochloride (WSCI HCl). We then blocked the residual -COOH groups on the Sensor Chip CM5 using ethanolamine. The immobilization response of His-tagged PD-L1 was 2793 RU. In the reference cell, we blocked all the -COOH groups of CM5 with ethanolamine. Then, we diluted the PD-1 Fc Chimera with the running buffer (1 × HBS-EP buffer) (Cytiva, MA, USA) to reach final concentrations of 0.001, 0.125, 0.25, 0.5, and 1.0 μM (100 μL of each). We then injected these solutions through a ligand or reference cell. We set the contact time at 60 s and the flow rate at 10 μL/min for PD-L1 capture. We regenerated the surface after each cycle using 10 mM glycine (pH 1.5) (Cytiva, MA, USA) at a flow rate of 30 μL/min for 30 s. We calculated the experimental Rmax using the Biacore T200 Evaluation Software version 1.0 and the Biacore 1 K+ Evaluation Software version 6.0 (Cytiva, MA, USA). Next, we diluted 2 or BMS-1 with the running buffer to reach final concentrations of 0.1 and 0.01 μM (containing 1% DMSO); we diluted the PD-1 Fc Chimera to 0.1 μM using the same buffer (containing 1% DMSO). Then, we pre-mixed the test compounds (10 μL; final concentrations: 0.1 or 0.01 μM) and PD-1 Fc Chimera (90 μL; final concentration: 0.1 μM) for 60 min at room temperature (r.t.) and injected these solutions (100 μL) through a ligand or reference cell. We calculated the experimental Rmax using the Biacore Evaluation software. For the binding assays of 2 to PD-L1 or PD-1, we injected His-tagged PD-L1 (final concentration, 1.0 μM, pH 6.0) or PD-1 Fc Chimera (final concentration, 1.0 μM, pH 4.0) on a Biacore Sensor Chip CM5 to immobilize them. The immobilization responses of His-tagged PD-L1 and PD-1 Fc Chimera were 138.4 and 155.5 RU, respectively. Then, we diluted 2 with the running buffer to reach final concentrations of 0.01, 0.1, 0.5, and 1.0 μM (100 μL of each, containing 5% DMSO) and injected them through a ligand or reference cell. We performed the affinity analysis at r.t. We calculated the Rmax and KD values using the Biacore T200 Evaluation software and Excel.

sec.title: Effects of BMS-1, CA-170, BMS-1166, 2, 5, and 11 on the viability of Jurkat (E6-1) and MDA-MB-231 cells
sec.p: We seeded Jurkat (E6-1) (4 × 104 cells/well) and MDA-MB-231 (2 × 104 cells/well) cells onto standard 96-well microtiter plates. Following 24 h of culture, we added the test compounds (1, 10, or 100 μM) to the wells. After 24 h of incubation, we evaluated cell growth using a WST-8 assay kit (Dojindo, Kumamoto, Japan).

sec.title: T cell activation recovery assay
sec.p: We cultured Jurkat (E6-1) cells in RPMI 1640 Medium (Nacalai Tesque, Kyoto, Japan) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) (Sigma-Aldrich, MO, USA) and 0.5% penicillin/streptomycin at 37 °C in a 95% air and 5% CO2 humidified incubator. To an aliquot (10 mL (1 × 106–1 × 107 cells/mL)) of this culture medium, we added ImmunoCult™ Human CD3/CD28 T cell activator (250 μL) (Stem Cell Technologies, Vancouver, BC, Canada). After incubating for 72 h, we monitored T cell activation by measuring IL-2 and IFN-γ production using a strips-type ELISA plate (Sepaplate-8F, Sumitomo Bakelite Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). Meanwhile, we cultured the MDA-MB-231 cells in DMEM containing 10% FBS and 0.5% penicillin/streptomycin, seeded them in 96-well plates at 1 × 104 cells/well, and incubated them for 24 h. Then, we added the T cell-activated Jurkat cell culture solution (100 μL) containing 4 × 104 cells and the test compound (1, 10, or 100 μM) to the 96-well plate with the MDA-MB-231 cell culture solution, and incubated for 24 h. We then collected the supernatants and evaluated the production of IL-2 and IFN-γ using the ELISA MAX Deluxe Set Human IL-2 (Biolegend, CA, USA) and ELISA MAX™ Deluxe Set Human IFN-γ (Biolegend, CA, USA).
In the same way, we tested the cytokine levels in MDA-MB-231 and anti-CD3/CD28-activated Jurkat (E6-1) cell culture solutions, respectively, without or with a test compound.

sec.title: Molecular docking
sec.p: As a PD-L1 structure reference, we used the X-ray data of BMS-202 co-crystallized with PD-L1 (PDB: 5J89). We docked 2 with PD-L1 using MOE 2022.09, with Amber10: EHT as the force field. We used standard protocols for general docking. We ranked the obtained docked poses using the London dG score, then performed force field refinement for the top 30 poses, and rescored them using GBVI/WSA dG (Induced Fit).

sec.title: Mouse experiments
sec.p: Female BALB/c mice (5–6 weeks old) were purchased from Japan SLC (Shizuoka, Japan). On day 0, mice (n = 10 per group) were intranasally infected with 2 × 104 PFU of IFV in 50 μL of PBS. They then received orally 2, 7 (each 1 mg/0.4 mL distilled water), or oseltamivir phosphate (Chugai Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) (0.2 mg/0.4 mL distilled water) once a day (at 9:00 am) from day 0 to day 14, beginning 5 min after virus infection. Control mice received 0.4 mL of vehicle (distilled water). Body weight and mortality were monitored for 14 days after virus inoculation. On day 3, lung samples were collected from each group (n = 5 per group), treated with 1 μL of PBS per mg of lung tissue, sonicated for 10 s, and centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 30 min. The supernatants were stored at − 80 °C. Virus titers of these samples were determined by plaque assay on MDCK cell monolayers. Blood samples and BALFs were collected from each group on days 3 and 14. The blood samples were centrifuged them at 3000 rpm for 10 min, and the sera were stored at − 20 °C. BALF samples were prepared by performing four washes with 0.8 mL of ice-cold PBS using a tracheal cannula, centrifuged them at 1500 rpm for 10 min, and the supernatants were stored at − 80 °C. Neutralizing antibody titers on days 3 and 14 were determined by performing a 50% plaque reduction assay as previously described55.

sec.title: In vitro anti-IFV assays
sec.p: Compound 2 was dissolved in DMSO. The working solutions of 2 and control without 2 contained < 0.2% DMSO, which did not interfere with the growth of both MDCK cells and IFV (see Sect. 7 in Supplementary Information). For cytotoxicity assay, MDCK cells were seeded at a density of 1 × 104 cells/well in 96-well plates. After 24 h incubation at 37 °C, the cells were cultured for 72 h in the presence of 2 (0–1000 µg/mL). Viable cell yields were determined by the trypan blue exclusion test. The inhibition data were plotted as dose–response curves, from which the 50% cell growth inhibitory concentration (CC50) was obtained. In anti-IFV assays, the plaque yield reduction assay was employed. MDCK cell monolayers in 48-well plates were infected with IFV at 0.1 plaque-forming unit (PFU)/cell for 1 h at r.t. (26 °C). After washing the cell monolayers with phosphate-buffered saline the cells were further incubated at 37 °C for 24 h in the presence of 2. Virus yields in each well were determined using plaque assays, and the 50% effective concentration (EC50) was obtained from the concentration–response curves. The antiviral activity of 2 against IFV was estimated using the selectivity index calculated from the CC50 and EC50. Data are shown as the mean ± SD from independent triplicate assays.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data are expressed as the mean ± standard deviation. We compared the samples with the control using student’s t-tests.

sec.title: Reporting summary
sec.p: Further information on the research design is available in the Nature Reporting Summary linked to this article.

fn.p: Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We thank MS Hinata Nishino and BS He Zhaoyang at Kansai University for their assistance with the ELISA measurements, synthesis of some inhibitors, and measurement of NMR and MS spectra. We also thank Dr. Yasuyuki Kawaratani and MS Akinori Kozatani at Kansai University for their support in constructing the sulfur-containing compound library.

notes.p: S.U. and Y.H. contributed equally to this work. S.U. supervised the entire study and drafted the manuscript. S.U., Y.H., Y.N., K.H., T.K., and M.D. interpreted data and approved the final manuscript. S.U. designed and supervised the synthesis of the evaluated compounds. Y.H. performed all in vitro assays. K.H. performed the in vivo virus infection experiments. T.K. and M.D. conducted the molecular docking simulations.
The data generated or analyzed during this study are included in this published article and its supplementary information files. The data are available upon request from the corresponding author.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
